;

;（这篇 10 月 25 日的报道已更正，将第 4 段中的名字更改为卡先生）

;

;数百名警察在刘易斯顿市和缅因州周边地区搜寻一名因酒吧和保龄球馆大规模枪击事件而被通缉的男子，新闻媒体报道死亡人数从 16 人到 22 人不等，其中数十人死亡更多人受伤。

;

;官员称有多人伤亡，但拒绝提供数字。

;

;州和当地警方确认 40 岁的罗伯特·R·卡德 (Robert R. Card) 是此案的相关人员。此前，他曾在脸书上发布过一名男子挥舞着半自动步枪的照片。周三犯罪现场的照片显示，一名身穿棕色连帽衫和牛仔裤的留着胡须的男子，将武器保持在射击位置。

;

;“我们实际上有数百名警察在缅因州各地工作进行调查。缅因州公共安全专员迈克·索舒克 (Mike Sauschuck) 在新闻发布会上表示：“此案的目的是找到卡德先生，他是一名嫌疑人。”

;

;多家媒体报道称，缅因州执法公告称卡德先生是一名训练有素的枪械教练美国陆军预备役军人最近报告说他有心理健康问题，包括听力问题。声明还称，他威胁要向国民警卫队基地开枪。

;

;“据报道，卡德于 2023 年夏季被送往精神卫生机构两周，随后被释放，”缅因州通知称信息与分析中心。

;

;路透社无法验证该公告。据美联社报道，该消息已分发给执法官员。

;

;这家酒吧和保龄球馆位于刘易斯顿，相距约 4 英里（6.5 公里）。刘易斯顿是安德罗斯科金县的一个前纺织中心，也是一个拥有 38,000 人的小镇，大约有 38,000 人。缅因州最大城市波特兰以北 35 英里（56 公里）处。

;

;路透社早些时候获得的媒体报道称，沃尔玛配送中心存在第三个枪击地点，但沃尔玛随后向当地媒体发表声明表示他们的财产上没有发生枪击事件。

;

;刘易斯顿的缅因州中央医疗中心发表声明称，它正在“对大规模伤亡和大规模枪击事件做出反应”，并与地区医院协调收治患者。

;

; p>;

;美国官员在华盛顿表示，总统乔·拜登已听取情况通报，并将继续收到最新消息。

;

;总统分别与缅因州州长珍妮特·米尔斯、参议员安格斯·金和苏珊·柯林斯通电话白宫表示，国会议员贾里德·戈尔登就刘易斯顿枪击事件表示支持，并在袭击发生后表示提供联邦政府的全力支持。

;

;如果确认死亡人数为 22 人，这将是美国最严重的屠杀事件。据枪支暴力档案馆称，至少自 2019 年 8 月起，一名枪手在埃尔帕索沃尔玛用 AK-47 步枪向购物者开枪，造成 23 人死亡，检察官将这起枪击事件定性为反西班牙裔仇恨犯罪。

;

;这 22 人死亡也与缅因州任何一年通常发生的凶杀案数量相当。据缅因州警方称，自 2012 年以来，该州每年的凶杀案数量在 16 起至 29 起之间波动。

;

;自 COVID-19 疫情以来，美国四人或以上枪击事件数量激增根据档案数据，根据截至 7 月的趋势，流感大流行于 2020 年开始，2022 年发生 647 起，预计 2023 年将发生 679 起。

;

;美国有记录以来最致命的大规模枪击事件是2017 年，一名枪手在拉斯维加斯乡村音乐节上从高层酒店的高处向 58 人开枪。

; Thu, 26 Oct 2023 12:55:04 +0800 US third-quarter economic growth seen fastest in nearly 2 yearshttps://reuters.com/article/usa-economy/us-third-quarter-economic-growth-seen-fastest-in-nearly-2-years-idUSKBN31Q09J
;;2023-10-26T04:04:48Z;
;;
;;2022 年 3 月 29 日，美国纽约市布鲁克林的一家商店展示水果和蔬菜的价格。REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/档案照片;
;

;美国经济第三季度可能以近两年来最快的速度增长，再次无视经济衰退的可怕警告，因为紧缩的工资导致工资上涨劳动力市场帮助推动了消费者支出。

;

;美国商务部周四对第三季度国内生产总值的预先估计也预计将显示住宅投资在连续九个季度下降后出现反弹。随着工厂建设的提振作用逐渐减弱，商业投资据信已经放缓。乔·拜登总统的政府已采取措施鼓励美国增加半导体制造

;

;虽然上个季度预期的强劲增长速度可能无法持续，但这将证明尽管美联储大幅加息，经济仍具有韧性预订。尽管如此，由于美国汽车工人联合会罢工和数百万美国人恢复学生贷款偿还，第四季度的增长可能会放缓。

;

;大多数经济学家都;修改了他们的预测;，现在相信美联储可以设计“软着陆” “对于经济而言，预期 7 月至 9 月期间将显示第二季度工人生产率将持续强劲，单位劳动力成本将有所放缓。

;

;“我们看到的情况恰恰相反（即多伦多 BMO 资本市场高级经济学家萨尔·瓜蒂耶里 (Sal Guatieri) 表示。 “作为美国经济最大引擎的美国消费者似乎在年中复苏，主要是因为整个夏季股市上涨和汽油价格稳定，信心有所改善。”

;

;路透社对经济学家的调查显示，上季度 GDP 折年率可能增长 4.3%，这将是 2021 年第四季度以来最快的。4 月至 6 月季度经济增长 2.1%，扩张速度为这一速度远高于美联储官员所认为的约 1.8% 的非通胀增长率。;

;预估范围从低至 2.5% 到高达 6.0%，反映了较大幅度的差距一些输入数据，包括9月份耐用品订单、货物贸易赤字、批发和零售库存数据将与GDP报告同时公布。

;

;消费者支出，占GDP的比重超过两倍美国经济活动的三分之一可能是主要驱动力，美国人购买机动车辆等耐用商品以及参加音乐会。由于价格下降，商品支出似乎大幅增加。

;

;强劲的劳动力市场支撑了消费者支出。尽管工资增长放缓，但其增长速度略快于通胀，从而提高了家庭的购买力。消费者支出增速预计将超过 4.0%，第二季度仅增长 0.8%。

;

;学生贷款偿还额于 10 月份恢复，经济学家估计约为 700 亿美元，或个人可支配收入的 0.3% 左右，并可能减少支出。尽管疫情期间积累的超额储蓄仍然充足，但主要集中在高收入家庭。

;

;低收入消费者越来越依赖债务来为购买提供资金，借贷成本上升导致信用卡拖欠率上升。< /p>;

;因此，一些经济学家认为经济即将大幅放缓。其他人并不太担心，他们指出劳动力市场继续强劲地创造就业机会。

;

;“我们看到有关信用卡债务增长过快的可怕头条新闻，但在大流行期间已经下降了很多”，费城威尔明顿信托公司首席经济学家卢克·蒂利说。 “当你把它看作人们每月收入的一部分时，它实际上是相当正常的。我认为我们还没有达到煤矿里的金丝雀的地步。”

;

;劳工部周四发布的另一份报告应能体现出劳动力市场的韧性，该报告预计上周初请失业金人数将较前一周的九个月低点小幅上升。

;

;GDP数据可能不会影响短期货币政策，因为随着美国国债收益率飙升而股市下跌，金融状况已经收紧。

;

;金融市场预计美联储将维持利率不变10月31日至11月31日不变根据芝商所 (CME Group) 的 FedWatch 数据，1 日政策会议。自3月份以来，美联储自2022年3月起已将基准隔夜利率上调525个基点，至目前的5.25%至5.50%区间。

;

;“我认为（强劲的GDP报告）已经融入他们的思维，”法国巴黎银行驻纽约的高级经济学家叶莲娜·舒利亚蒂耶娃(Yelena Shulyatyeva)说。 “我们认为，我们已经达到了这个商业周期的最终速度。”

;

;由于出口强劲和库存投资增加，贸易逆差较小也提振了上季度的增长。预计九月中旬开始的汽车罢工不会产生影响。但劳资纠纷每周给汽车制造商造成数百万美元的损失，可能会影响第四季度的增长。

;

;“我认为罢工导致了增速放缓，”经济学家布赖恩·贝休恩 (Brian Bethune) 表示。波士顿学院教授。 “但我不认为我们会突然被扔到海里。”

; Thu, 26 Oct 2023 12:25:03 +0800 Mideast in focus as US, China meet to pave way for Biden-Xi summithttps://reuters.com/article/usa-china/mideast-in-focus-as-us-china-meet-to-pave-way-for-biden-xi-summit-idUSKBN31Q09N
;;2023-10-26T04:05:07Z;
;;
;;2022 年 7 月 9 日，美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯在印度尼西亚巴厘岛努沙杜瓦会见中国外交部长王毅。 Stefani Reynolds/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo;
;

;中国外交部长王毅开始访问;期待已久的周四访问;，美国和中国寻求解决深刻的战略分歧，并为预期的两国元首峰会铺平道路乔·拜登和习近平。

;

;中东战争为超级大国之间的紧张关系增添了新的活力，华盛顿希望北京能够利用其对伊朗的影响力来帮助确保;以色列与哈马斯冲突;不会蔓延到更广泛的地区。;

;然而，虽然北京和华盛顿都谈到寻找可以合作的领域，但习近平周三表示，中国;愿意就全球挑战进行合作;，但专家预计不会立即取得进展。

;

;拜登政府与北京的首要任务是防止世界最大的两个经济体之间的激烈竞争以及在一系列问题上的分歧;对台贸易;和南中国海陷入冲突。

;

;美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯将于周四在国务院欢迎王毅，他于周二向联合国安理会表示他将;与他合作;防止中东冲突蔓延。

;

;中国和美国的政策分析人士表示，避免更广泛的战争符合双方的共同利益，而且中国作为主要石油购买国，可以对其施加相当大的影响。

;

;但北京是否会使用它还有待观察，专家表示中国可能会在场外观望一段时间。

;

;“中国人当然有兴趣阻止华盛顿战略与国际研究中心中东项目负责人乔恩·奥尔特曼表示：“这将是美国与伊朗之间的直接对抗，因为它们是主要的石油消费国，这将导致油价上涨。”

;

;“尽管如此，中国人不太可能在这里做任何繁重的工作。我预计，当以色列与加沙的斗争得到解决时，他们会希望在谈判桌上占有一席之地，但他们觉得没有太大必要或能力来加速解决。”

;

;时殷弘，教授，国际关系学教授中国人民大学表示，北京对伊朗施加影响“几乎是美国对中国在中东局势上唯一严肃而实际的期望。”

;

;但时补充道：“美国对伊朗的立场远非如此。”中国可以接受，反之亦然。在这个问题上的相互妥协可能太有限、太小，没有任何意义。”

;

;华盛顿强调了中国影响伊朗的能力的重要性。布林肯在;旋风式中东之旅;上周，给王通电话询问利用北京的影响力确保冲突不会扩大。

;

;中国呼吁各方克制并停火，以回应以色列对加沙的轰炸，以报复哈马斯 10 月 7 日的袭击，以色列称此次袭击造成 1,400 人死亡哈马斯统治的加沙卫生部周三表示，以色列的报复性空袭已造成 6,500 多人死亡。路透社无法独立核实双方的伤亡数字。

;

;“中国一直在不懈地努力促进停止敌对行动和恢复和平。我们一直与有关方面保持密切沟通。”中国驻联合国大使张军周二表示。

;

;王毅此次访问华盛顿是在包括布林肯在内的多位美国高级官员过去几个月访问北京之后。

;

;这位资深的中国外交官预计将于周五会见拜登的国家安全顾问杰克·沙利文。他是;预计拜登在访问白宫期间将与他交谈;，但目前尚不清楚他们的互动有多大

;

;分析人士预计，讨论的重点是拜登和习近平将于 11 月 11 日至 17 日在旧金山举行的亚太经合组织 (APEC) 国家峰会期间举行的会晤的准备工作。 . 这将是拜登和习近平自上次;巴厘岛峰会;以来的首次面对面会面11月。

;

;“有实质性的事情需要解决和敲定，”华盛顿史汀生中心中国项目主任孙云说。 “（王）只会来这里进行谈判——重大成果将留待最高领导人宣布。”

;

;周三，习近平表示华盛顿和北京能否建立“正确”的谈判方式相处并管理分歧对世界至关重要。

;

;双方从不同的经济角度进入 APEC，经济政策分析师表示，在 COVID-19 大流行之后，美国在一定程度上经受住了充满挑战的全球形势比中国更好。

;

;美国和中国官员周一举行了一次虚拟会议;宏观经济发展;，美国称会谈“富有成效和实质性”，中国称会谈“深入、坦诚和建设性”。

;

;美国官员表示，台湾以及南海和东海，他们指责北京对竞争对手的领土主张者采取“破坏稳定和危险的行动”，这也将被列入议程。

;

;他们表示，与中国重建军事关系仍然是美国应避免的首要任务

;

;中国《环球时报》小报强调了两国关系的矛盾。

;

;“虽然中美在不同领域的互动迅速恢复”，但美国试图“遏制”的政策声明称，中国没有改变，并指责华盛顿采取“双面策略”，“频繁利用各种机会抹黑中国、制造摩擦”。

; Thu, 26 Oct 2023 12:25:03 +0800 Israel bombards Gaza as Putin warns conflict could spread beyond Middle Easthttps://reuters.com/article/israel-palestinians/israel-bombards-gaza-as-putin-warns-conflict-could-spread-beyond-middle-east-idUSKBN31P2C2

;

;以色列轰炸加沙地带，因为它正在准备;地面入侵; 称其目的是消灭巴勒斯坦激进组织哈马斯，俄罗斯警告冲突可能蔓延到中东以外地区.

;

;在被围困的加沙，人道主义供应严重不足，;世界大国未能;就停止提供援助的战斗达成一致，随着平民伤亡人数不断增加，居民将死者埋在万人坑中。

;

;美国总统乔·拜登周三，在;展望战争之外;的讲话中表示，未来应该包括以色列和巴勒斯坦国家并肩作战。

;

;“以色列人和巴勒斯坦人同样应该安全、有尊严、和平地毗邻共存，”拜登在华盛顿与来访的联合新闻发布会上表示。澳大利亚总理安东尼·阿尔巴内塞。

;

;拜登表示，他认为伊朗支持的哈马斯于 10 月 7 日袭击以色列南部，造成至少 1,400 人死亡并劫持人质，原因之一是阻止以色列和以色列之间关系正常化。沙特阿拉伯。

;

;俄罗斯总统弗拉基米尔·普京警告称，冲突可能会蔓延至中东以外地区，并表示加沙无辜妇女、儿童和老人因他人的罪行而受到惩罚，这是错误的。

;

;根据克里姆林宫的记录，普京在与不同信仰的俄罗斯宗教领袖会面时表示，“我们今天的任务，我们的主要任务，是制止流血和暴力。”

;

;“否则，危机的进一步升级会带来严重、极其危险和破坏性的后果。而且不仅适用于中东地区。它可能会蔓延到远远超出中东边界的地区。”

;

;周三，保龄球馆等多个地点发生大规模枪击事件，造成至少 22 人死亡、50 至 60 人受伤。 NBC新闻援引刘易斯顿警方消息人士的话说，缅因州刘易斯顿的一家酒吧发生了枪击事件。

;

;州和当地警方此前报告称，周三晚上发生了一名活跃的枪手，他们正在搜寻一名在逃嫌疑人，但没有提供伤亡数字。

;刘易斯顿警察局发布了三张嫌疑人指着一把似乎是半自动步枪的照片，以及一张白色SUV的照片，请求公众帮助in identifying either.

;

;The Androscoggin County Sheriff's Office also posted pictures of the suspect, a bearded man in a brown hoodie jacket and jeans holding a rifle in the firing position.

;

;"There is an active shooter in Lewiston," Maine state police said on the social media platform X. "We ask people to shelter in place. Please stay inside your home with the doors locked. Law enforcement is currently investigating at multiple locations."

;

;The Sun Journal, citing a Lewiston police spokesperson, reported shootings at three separate businesses: the Sparetime Recreation bowling alley, Schemengees Bar & Grille Restaurant, and a Walmart distribution center.

;

;The bowling alley is about four miles (6.5 km) north of the bar, and the distribution center is about a mile and a half (2.5 km) south of the bar.

;

;The Central Maine Medical Center in Lewiston issued a statement saying it was "reacting to a mass casualty, mass shooter event" and coordinating with area hospitals to take patients.

;

;Lewiston is part of and about 35 miles (56 km) north of Maine's largest city, Portland.

;

;Lewiston, a former textile hub and town of 38,000 people in Androscoggin County, is located in southern Maine about midway between the state capital, Augusta, and Portland, the state's most populous city

;

;President Joe Biden has been briefed and will continue to receive updates, a US official said in Washington.

;

;The president spoke by phone individually to Maine Governor Janet Mills, Senators Angus King and Susan Collins, and Congressman Jared Golden about the shooting in Lewiston and offered full federal support in the wake of the attack, the White House said.

;

;If the death toll of 22 is confirmed, the massacre would be the deadliest in the United States since at least August 2019, when a gunman opened fire on shoppers at an El Paso Walmart with an AK-47 rifle, killing 23 in a shooting that prosecutors branded an anti-Hispanic hate crime, according to the Gun Violence Archive.

;

;The 22 fatalities would also be on par with the number of homicides that normally occur in Maine in any given year. The number of annual homicides in the state has fluctuated between 16 and 29 since 2012, according to Maine State Police.

;

;The number of US shootings in which four or more people were shot has surged since the COVID-19 pandemic began in 2020, with 647 occurring in 2022 and 679 projected to occur in 2023, based on trends as of July, according to data from the archive.

;

;The deadliest US mass shooting on record is the massacre of 58 people by a gunman firing on a Las Vegas country music festival from a high-rise hotel perch in 2017.

;;US President Joe Biden and First lady Jill Biden on Tuesday (October 24) welcomed Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and his partner Jodie Haydon to the White House ahead of an official state visit.;
;

;US President Joe Biden said on Wednesday a "path toward peace" must be forged once the ;Israel-Gaza crisis; concludes, with independent states for the Israelis and Palestinians and an integration of Israel among its Arab neighbors.

;

;Biden opened a ;joint news conference; with Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese by saying US support for Israel's defense was ironclad, but the parties needed to think about a way forward in the region once the Gaza crisis was resolved.

;

;"Israelis and Palestinians equally deserve to live side by side in safety, dignity and peace," Biden said.

;

;"When this crisis is over, there has to be a vision of what comes next. And in our view, it has to be a two-state solution. It means a concentrated effort from all the parties - Israelis, Palestinians, regional partners, global leaders - to put us on a path toward peace," Biden said.

;

;Biden said he believed one reason Hamas militants attacked southern Israel, killing 1,400 people on Oct. 7, was to prevent normalizing relations between ;Israel and Saudi Arabia;. Israeli airstrikes in retaliation have ;killed over 6,500 people;, the health ministry in Hamas-ruled Gaza said on Wednesday. Reuters has not been able to independently verify the casualty figures of either side.

;

;Biden said he had "no notion" that the Palestinians were telling the truth about how many had been killed.

;

;"I'm sure innocents have been killed, and it's the price of waging a war," he said. "I have no confidence in the number that the Palestinians are using."

;

;Biden did not elaborate but also expressed concern about treatment of Palestinians by some Israelis.

;

;"I continue to be alarmed about extremist settlers attacking Palestinians in the West Bank," Biden said, accusing them of pouring gasoline on a fire. "They're attacking Palestinians in places that they're entitled to be, and it has to stop."

;

;The Council on American-Islamic Relations (CAIR), a Muslim civil rights and advocacy group, called Biden's remarks about Palestinian casualties "dehumanizing."

;

;“President Biden should apologize for his comments, condemn the Israeli government for deliberately targeting civilians, and demand a ceasefire before more innocent people die,” CAIR Executive Director Nihad Awad said in a statement.

;

;Albanese, in his opening remarks, said Australia will provide an additional $15 million in aid for Gaza civilians.

;

;Earlier, at a White House arrival ceremony, he called American leadership indispensable but not inevitable.

;

;"It takes a leader to deliver it. It takes wisdom to show empathy, courage to provide humanitarian assistance, and true leadership to seek peace. Because protecting innocent people is not a show of weakness. It is a measure of strength," he said.

;

;A growing chorus of nations are pushing Israel to take a humanitarian pause in its attacks on Hamas in Gaza that have killed thousands of Palestinians, many of them children. Biden, a ;self-described "Zionist";, has strongly supported Israel following Hamas' Oct. 7 attack while cautioning the country to abide by democratic principles.

;

;Australia is a key ally in the Pacific, and Biden scheduled the visit after ;canceling a trip to Sydney; in May to stay in Washington and negotiate a government funding crisis.

;

;Biden appeared to issue China a warning after a series of ;maritime confrontations; with the Philippines, saying the United States' commitment to Manila's defense is iron clad.

;

;China is having its own internal and external difficulties right now, Biden added.

;

;The US-Australia alliance is "marked by imagination, ingenuity and innovation," Biden told the prime minister in opening remarks upon his arrival at the White House, citing their partnership in World War One, World War Two and the "war on terror."

;

;The visit resulted in agreements aimed at deterring and competing with China, even as separately the two countries try to thaw relations with Beijing. The two nations are committed to making sure the "Indo-Pacific remains free, open, prosperous and secure," Biden said.

;

;Albanese, greeted with a red carpet, military band and a receiving line of Biden's top advisers, praised American democratic values and lauded Biden for maintaining "that every innocent life matters, Israeli and Palestinian, and that in every conflict every effort must be made to protect civilians."

;

;He also pledged continued cooperation in Ukraine's ongoing fight against Russia's invasion last year.

;

;Later in the evening the two men attended an elaborate state dinner, though a planned performance by the B-52's was ;scrapped; out of respect for those suffering in the Middle East.

;

;The deals between the two sides included an ;undersea internet cable project; and maritime wharf infrastructure investment designed to benefit and woo Pacific Island nations whose assistance may be needed to respond to any future ;conflict over Taiwan; or the South China Sea.

;

;Washington and Canberra, already partners in a decades-old collective defense agreement, also announced wider security cooperation with Japan.

;

;The balancing act of strengthening deterrence against China without offending Beijing too much is made more complicated by a Middle East crisis that has again diverted Washington's attention away from the Indo-Pacific.

;

;Russia made a rival proposal that advocated a wider ceasefire, but failed to win the minimum number of votes. Israel has resisted both, arguing that Hamas would only take advantage and create new threats to Gaza civilians.

;

;As the death toll mounts in Gaza, Palestinians are burying the unidentified dead in mass graves, with a number instead of a name, residents say.

;

;Some families are using ;bracelets; in the hope of finding their loved ones should they be killed.

;Israeli retaliatory strikes have killed over 6,500 people, the health ministry in the Hamas-run strip said on Wednesday. Reuters has been unable to independently verify the casualty figures of either side.

;;
;;Hurricane Otis roared into Mexico as a Category 5 storm early on Wednesday (October 25), with torrential rain and fierce winds battering the beach resort of Acapulco. Olivia Zollino has more.;
;

;Hurricane Otis, one of the strongest storms ever to hit Mexico's Pacific Coast, roared into the beach resort of Acapulco early on Wednesday, smashing buildings and vital infrastructure and leaving the city incommunicado and without power.

;

;Footage on social media showed hotels wrecked by Otis, ceilings and walls ripped open, windows shattered and cars partly submerged in floodwaters as the rare Category 5 storm barreled ashore in the southern state of Guerrero.

;

;Debris was strewn around lobbies, patios, streets and hotel balconies, and remnants of mangled trees littered downtown Acapulco. Downed telecommunication lines and damage to infrastructure left residents cut off from the outside world.

;

;The airport for the city of nearly 900,000 people was closed until further notice, the transport ministry said, after it lost power and nearby roads were blocked due to Otis.

;

;President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador set off for Acapulco by car to lend support, but was held up due to road closures caused by the storm, video footage on social media showed.

;

;There were no immediate reports of fatalities, but the power outages made it hard for officials to assess the extent of the destruction. Some officials privately expressed concern that Otis would likely have caused some loss of life.

;

;Luisa Pena, a shaken hotel guest in Acapulco, related how she hid in a closet after being caught in the eye of the storm.

;

;"I literally started to pray," she said in a video on TikTok. "Panic took hold of me to such an extent that all I asked for was just one more chance," she added, saying her room had been "destroyed" as Otis ripped through the building.

;

;Footage from one hospital on social media showed nurses evacuating patients from their rooms to keep them safe from Otis, which strengthened unexpectedly fast at sea and barreled into the coast with winds of 165 miles per hour (266 kph).

;

;The main highway connecting Acapulco to Mexico City would not be fully open until Thursday, the government said as it mobilized the military to help clear up the mess.

;

;Otis reached the shore as a Category 5 - the strongest level on the five-step Saffir-Simpson hurricane wind scale - before quickly weakening to a Category 4 storm. Its power slackened further as it moved inland, reducing Otis to a tropical storm and later dissipating over the mountains of southern Mexico.

;

;Mexican authorities expressed shock at the power of Otis, as the weather front was initially expected only to be a tropical storm. But it quickly grew in strength as it neared the coast.

;

;Otis plowed in to the Pacific coast almost exactly eight years after Hurricane Patricia, a storm that whipped up winds of 200 miles per hour (322 kph).

;

;The US National Hurricane Center warned of heavy rains in southwestern and south-central Mexico through Thursday and a continued risk of lethal flooding and mudslides.

;

;Authorities had previously said Otis could bring up to 20 inches (51 cm) of rain to parts of Guerrero and Oaxaca states, mudslides, a "potentially catastrophic" storm surge, and life-threatening surf and rip current conditions.

;

;Power outages were reported throughout Guerrero, affecting hundreds of thousands, while flights to and from Acapulco were suspended and school classes canceled.

;

;The government said the airport suffered extensive damage, with the hurricane smashing the control tower's windows.
